conclusion: Four different objects stand on a flat slab floor: a vertical glove-shaped object, a low ticket-punch/stapler, a tall thin bird/leaf figure, and a small peach.
The red arrows A, B, C, D point to the ground shadows of the four objects.
The light is behind the line of objects (farther away from the camera) and somewhat above them; therefore every shadow is cast toward the camera, i.e., toward the bottom of the image.
Treat every object as standing on the ground with top height h. Take the ground as z = 0, the light as a point (xL, yL, zL) where zL ≫ 0, the center of an object as (x0, y0, 0) with height h.
The ray through the object’s top hits the floor at xS = x0 + (x0 – xL) · (zL / (zL – h)) and yS = y0 + (y0 – yL) · (zL / (zL – h)).

If the light moves only in the +y direction (toward the camera) while staying at the same height zL, then ΔyL < 0 (because it advances toward the camera), and the term (y0 – yL) in the formula passes from positive, through zero, to negative.
While yL is behind the object (y0 > yL), the product (y0 – yL) is positive, so the shadow lies in front of the object (toward the camera, as in the photo).
When the light is exactly above the object (y0 = yL), the product is zero, so the shadow shrinks to a point directly under the object.
After the light has passed in front of the object (y0 < yL), the product is negative, so the shadow jumps to the back side of the object (away from the camera).
The length of the shadow is proportional to h · |y0 – yL|, where h is the height of the object and |y0 – yL| is the distance between the object and the light source.
While the light approaches, |y0 – yL| gets smaller, so the shadow shortens.
When the light is overhead, |y0 – yL| = 0, so the shadow length is zero.
After passing overhead, |y0 – yL| grows again, so the shadow lengthens on the opposite side.
For a given light position, a taller object (larger h) always keeps the longer shadow.
Relative heights of the objects (visual estimate): C (bird) ≈ tallest > A (glove) > B (stapler) > D (peach) ≈ shortest.
